guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
If you believe Jesus was telling the truth when he said all would be fulfilled within the generation of his disciples, I think you have to be a Preterist. I didn't want to believe it, but it makes the most sense.

The book of Revelation itself is quite clear that the events described would happen soon, and John was writing to the Churches in Asia Minor, so he meant that it would explicitly be soon for them (unless you believe John was lying, in which case, you have to throw out Revelation entirely.)

But most Christians are hellbent on a physical utopia on Earth, the same mistake the Jews made in Christ's day. So they spin themselves fantastic apocalypses. This is particularly the case for modern Reformed Christians.

body: The antichrist was Nero Caesar, the man who began Christian persecution and burned Rome. We know this because the Greek reading of 666 when transliterated into Hebrew is his name. It's coded because the Christians were persecuted at the time, and such a declaration could have gotten even more Christians killed.

body:
>Why is there evil

Because man is fallen. That's true whether Christ is King or not, whether  Satan is defeated or not. Man has an evil nature, and in fact, it's actually so crucial to early neurodevelopment that if evil were gone, all children would become mentally handicapped.

Jesus' Kingdom is one of Spirit and of Temple. If you accept Christ, and you have found peace through the Holy Spirit (who is Christ, and the Father) then you are of the Kingdom of God, and you already rule with Christ.

There will probably never be a physical kingdom like the Jews wanted, no. There may be, but if it's the case, it's certainly not made clear in light of the New Testament. It's actually a running motif in Christ's teachings that most prophecy is fulfilled spiritually, not physically. John the Baptist as Elijah is a good example of this.

body:
Like a lot of the numerology lining up perfectly with Roman rulers. Like the fact that we actually have another number of the beast in some manuscript traditions (616) that also transliterate as Nero Caesar. The use of ancient Jewish Temple symbolism, alluding to the events of 70 AD. The persecution matching so precisely what happened in Rome. The fact that both Jesus and John say that all would be fulfilled within their generation, not thousands of years later. The fact that at this point Christianity is older than Israel/Jews were when Christ came, so it literally could not have been "the last days" this whole time by any straightforward interpretation. I could go on and on.

It's a pretty overwhelming case. I used to believe in all the futurist dispensation stuff, but it's just such an abstract stretch compared to the historic reading that I can't do it anymore, it doesn't makes sense. I'd go as far as to call a futurist reading postmodern, before postmodern thought existed.

The fact that at this point Christianity is older than Israel/Jews were when Christ came, so it literally could not have been "the last days" this whole time by any straightforward interpretation. I could go on and on.

It's a pretty overwhelming case. I used to believe in all the futurist dispensation stuff, but it's just such an abstract stretch compared to the historic reading that I can't do it anymore, it doesn't makes sense. I'd go as far as to call a futurist reading postmodern, before postmodern thought existed.

body:
That is false, the kingdom is not here yet. Read Isaiah 65:17-25.

“For behold, I create new heavens
    and a new earth,
and the former things shall not be remembered
    or come into mind.
18 But be glad and rejoice forever
    in that which I create;
for behold, I create Jerusalem to be a joy,
    and her people to be a gladness.
19 I will rejoice in Jerusalem
    and be glad in my people;
no more shall be heard in it the sound of weeping
    and the cry of distress.
20 No more shall there be in it
    an infant who lives but a few days,
    or an old man who does not fill out his days,
for the young man shall die a hundred years old,
    and the sinner a hundred years old shall be accursed.
21 They shall build houses and inhabit them;
    they shall plant vineyards and eat their fruit.
22 They shall not build and another inhabit;
    they shall not plant and another eat;
for like the days of a tree shall the days of my people be,
    and my chosen shall long enjoy[c] the work of their hands.
23 They shall not labor in vain
    or bear children for calamity,[d]
for they shall be the offspring of the blessed of the Lord,
    and their descendants with them.
24 Before they call I will answer;
    while they are yet speaking I will hear.
25 The wolf and the lamb shall graze together;
    the lion shall eat straw like the ox,
    and dust shall be the serpent's food.
They shall not hurt or destroy
    in all my holy mountain,”
says the Lord.

When has this ever happened, where is this being fulfilled?

Heaven is the Temple, where God dwells. This goes back to the Law of Moses. Earth is Judaism, the paradigm of practice.

Heaven and Earth are used in this way quite frequently throughout every religious tradition. But the bar for education has been lowered in recent centuries, and many hermeneutic rules forgotten.

We know it's a symbol, because if it were referring to a literal event on the scale of the Noahic flood, Heaven would not be destroyed. And the prophecies never otherwise mention Heaven being destroyed except in the context of temples/worship. So at the very least, Heaven has to be a metaphor. What are the chances that the prophets would mix the physical and the spiritual in this context? Very low, I'd say, because it's a far more confusing reading.

You can also go down the road of Jewish interpretation of the end of days. They have always divided the history of the World into 2 eras; The Current Era, and the Era to Come. I think their paradigm is correct, their aren't 3 eras, only 2, and we're in the 2nd, because Christ already atoned for the World and destroyed the Old Sacrificial Covenant.

That is false, the kingdom is not here yet. Read Isaiah 65:17-25.

“For behold, I create new heavens
    and a new earth,
and the former things shall not be remembered
    or come into mind.
18 But be glad and rejoice forever
    in that which I create;
for behold, I create Jerusalem to be a joy,
    and her people to be a gladness.
19 I will rejoice in Jerusalem
    and be glad in my people;
no more shall be heard in it the sound of weeping
    and the cry of distress.
20 No more shall there be in it
    an infant who lives but a few days,
    or an old man who does not fill out his days,
for the young man shall die a hundred years old,
    and the sinner a hundred years old shall be accursed.
21 They shall build houses and inhabit them;
    they shall plant vineyards and eat their fruit.
22 They shall not build and another inhabit;
    they shall not plant and another eat;
for like the days of a tree shall the days of my people be,
    and my chosen shall long enjoy[c] the work of their hands.
23 They shall not labor in vain
    or bear children for calamity,[d]
for they shall be the offspring of the blessed of the Lord,
    and their descendants with them.
24 Before they call I will answer;
    while they are yet speaking I will hear.
25 The wolf and the lamb shall graze together;
    the lion shall eat straw like the ox,
    and dust shall be the serpent's food.
They shall not hurt or destroy
    in all my holy mountain,”
says the Lord.

When has this ever happened, where is this being fulfilled?

parent.body:
If you believe Jesus was telling the truth when he said all would be fulfilled within the generation of his disciples, I think you have to be a Preterist. I didn't want to believe it, but it makes the most sense.

The book of Revelation itself is quite clear that the events described would happen soon, and John was writing to the Churches in Asia Minor, so he meant that it would explicitly be soon for them (unless you believe John was lying, in which case, you have to throw out Revelation entirely.)

But most Christians are hellbent on a physical utopia on Earth, the same mistake the Jews made in Christ's day. So they spin themselves fantastic apocalypses. This is particularly the case for modern Reformed Christians.

body:
Well, that's a complicated question, and not necessarily because I don't have an answer for it, but because the Bible doesn't actually say that much on the afterlife to begin with.

Off the top of my head, I'd say nothing substantial changes, necessarily. Except, I'd say that many of Christ's statements that are interpreted as Hell are more likely prognostications of the Hell on Earth that was the destruction of Jerusalem, a separate concept from the literal Lake of Fire as described in the Book of Revelation.

So, whatever your tradition teaches, it's probably compatible with Preterism.

parent.body: The antichrist was Nero Caesar, the man who began Christian persecution and burned Rome. We know this because the Greek reading of 666 when transliterated into Hebrew is his name. It's coded because the Christians were persecuted at the time, and such a declaration could have gotten even more Christians killed.

body:
Everything in Matthew 24 happened. False Messiah's were a dime a dozen. There were a lot of natural disasters. The Roman Empire was on the verge of both Civil War and war with the Persian Empire. The Christians were persecuted. Christ did come in the sky and judge Jerusalem, both it and the entire Jewish religion were destroyed. Modern Judaism is basically a completely different religion after Temple sacrifice became impossible. Then all the followers did gather together, what is that but the Council of Nicaea?

I can't find anything in Matthew 24 that didn't happen already. Though I wouldn't be surprised if dispensationalists didn't actually know the history well enough to realized that it already happened.

body:
Well - when speaking to rapture - they mention verses 40 and 41 of that chapter where one is taken and the other is left before tribulation.

verse 40) Then shall two be in the field; the one shall be taken, and the other left.

verse 41) Two women shall be grinding at the mill; the one shall be taken, and the other left.

Also verse 29)  Immediately after the tribulation of those days shall the sun be darkened, and the moon shall not give her light, and the stars shall fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens shall be shaken:

but the dispensationalists still see the moon and the stars; but I suppose it an allegorical understanding vs a literal.  I wonder though if there was an astronomical anomaly after the sacking of Jerusalem.

verse 41) Two women shall be grinding at the mill; the one shall be taken, and the other left.

Also verse 29)  Immediately after the tribulation of those days shall the sun be darkened, and the moon shall not give her light, and the stars shall fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens shall be shaken:

but the dispensationalists still see the moon and the stars; but I suppose it an allegorical understanding vs a literal.  I wonder though if there was an astronomical anomaly after the sacking of Jerusalem.

body:
Right, for the first, I can only assume they didn't read the surrounding text. It's a command to be vigilant. These parable diatribes are a motif of Christ's teachings. It's not necessarily apocalyptic.

For the latter, the normal reading of that would be that the world would be shaken, and it was. Everything was destroyed, the Empire was shaken to its core, it was like their version of 9/11 but far worse.

Luckily, this particular metaphor is mirrored in Revelation 12, and it's explained to be a spiritual battle between God and Satan, not an astronomical phenomenon.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
I think Catholicism accepts a little of this but also rejects some of it:

[Catholic Encyclopedia on Anti-Christ](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01559a.htm)

Addendum: In reading the wiki page on the topic, I think Catholicism would reject full preterism but would accept partial preterism in some way, but I do not know for sure (the page mentions some Catholic support of preterist interpretations)
